all_posts: <div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/57-predictably-irrational-by-dan-ariely/"><h3>57: Predictably Irrational by Dan Ariely</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 21, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When it comes to making decisions, we like to think we’re capable of making smart, rational choices. But are we? Tune in to find out why Dan Ariely believe our irrational behavior is completely predictable - and what you can do about it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/57-predictably-irrational-by-dan-ariely/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/56-hyperfocus-by-and-with-chris-bailey/"><h3>56: Hyperfocus by (and with) Chris Bailey</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 6, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Focus is a hot topic, but there’s more to it then just turning off Twitter and blocking out distractions. Today’s book shows us how to manage our focus, helps us understand how it works, and shows us how to recharge it when it gets low. Author Chris Bailey joins us at the end to talk about writing Hyperfocus, what he learned from the process, and which mechanical keyboard is the best.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/56-hyperfocus-by-and-with-chris-bailey/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/55-the-happiness-advantage-by-shawn-achor/"><h3>55: The Happiness Advantage by Shawn Achor</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 18, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Happy people are productive people, but can you really choose to be happy? Things may not always happen for the best, but in today’s episode Mike &amp; Joe figure out how and why some people are able to make the best of the things that happen.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/55-the-happiness-advantage-by-shawn-achor/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/free-agents-58-a-better-path-with-joe-buhlig/"><h3>Free Agents 58: A Better Path, with Joe Buhlig</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 16, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/podcast-guest">podcast-guest</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>This past week I had a chance to jump on <a href="https://www.relay.fm/freeagents/58">Free Agents</a> with my good friends Mike Schmitz and David Sparks to talk about a pretty big transition I’m working through with my work. It may not be a popular decision I’m making, but it’s definitely the right move and I’m certainly excited about it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/free-agents-58-a-better-path-with-joe-buhlig/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/freeagents.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/33-its-where-the-widgets-are/"><h3>33: It’s Where the Widgets Are</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 15, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/whims">whims</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Joe has done something out of character, updating to iOS 12 and Mojave with quickness. Drew asks why, and the two talk about Siri Shortcuts, dark mode, and a third-party app that makes both of their MacBook Pro setups so much sweeter.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/33-its-where-the-widgets-are/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/whimsthatworklogo.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/54-work-clean-by-dan-charnas/"><h3>54: Work Clean by Dan Charnas</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 4, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Can the world of professional chefs teach us anything about productivity? Joe and Mike seem to agree with Dan Charnas and say, yes. Mis-en-place!</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/54-work-clean-by-dan-charnas/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/32-we-really-gotta-talk-about-team-management/"><h3>32: We Really Gotta Talk About Team Management</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 17, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/whims">whims</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>As Joe and Drew both grow their respective businesses, their usual task management talk transitions to a similar topic: team management. Drew gives the floor to Joe, who talks about why he manages projects and not people, and how to find the right system.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/32-we-really-gotta-talk-about-team-management/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/whimsthatworklogo.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/53-boundaries-by-henry-cloud/"><h3>53: Boundaries by Henry Cloud</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 5, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Should you set limits on what you’ll do with and for other people? And if so, what should those lines be? And do those limits have a place in the church?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/53-boundaries-by-henry-cloud/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/31-a-brick-and-mortar-space/"><h3>31: A Brick and Mortar Space</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 3, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/whims">whims</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Drew bought a coffee shop. He tells the story, and talks about how it’s changing his productivity habits.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/31-a-brick-and-mortar-space/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/whimsthatworklogo.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/52-the-power-of-habit-by-charles-duhigg/"><h3>52: The Power of Habit by Charles Duhigg</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 24, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Up to 40% of our daily actions are influenced by our habits, but how do you actually influence them? In this episode, Joe &amp; Mike dive into The Power of Habit and discover the secret to lasting positive change.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/52-the-power-of-habit-by-charles-duhigg/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/51-great-at-work-by-morten-hansen/"><h3>51: Great at Work by Morten Hansen</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 18, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>There is a myth in the workplace that says we need to work longer hours to achieve more and do so with higher quality. But this is purely a myth and there’s a lot of science to prove it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/51-great-at-work-by-morten-hansen/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/30-downtime-accountability-group/"><h3>30: Downtime Accountability Group</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 16, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/whims">whims</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Joe turns this episode into a confessional and makes a vulnerable statement: He’s a phone addict. Drew and Joe discuss our modern tendency to spend too much time on our devices, Joe reveals how he’s dealing with it, and Drew covers the ways that iOS 12 provides some ‘app limits’ of its own. Since iOS 12 gets brought up, so too does the other looming Apple beta: Mojave.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/30-downtime-accountability-group/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/whimsthatworklogo.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/50-2018-bookworm-draft/"><h3>50: 2018 Bookworm Draft</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 5, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>If you listen to Bookworm as a way to filter your book list, then this episode will blow your mind. Joe and Mike pick their top ten books draft-style. They’re not necessarily Bookworm books either. Also included: a special surprise.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/50-2018-bookworm-draft/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/29-back-to-a-digital-task-manager/"><h3>29: Back to a Digital Task Manager</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 2, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/whims">whims</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>An episode dedicated to a singular topic: Joe is back to using OmniFocus.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/29-back-to-a-digital-task-manager/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/whimsthatworklogo.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/49-peak-by-anders-ericsson/"><h3>49: Peak by Anders Ericsson</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 24, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>What does it take to become the best? And what do the world’s greatest do that puts them at the top? And how does that translate into our day to day lives?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/49-peak-by-anders-ericsson/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/28-move-from-one-phase-to-another/"><h3>28: Move from One Phase to Another</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 18, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/whims">whims</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Drew talks about his new business venture, Keyhouse! After Joe introduced Procourse last week, this conversation continues the same dialogue on freelance work becoming something bigger.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/28-move-from-one-phase-to-another/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/whimsthatworklogo.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/27-the-whole-working-on-the-internet-dilemma/"><h3>27: The Whole Working on the Internet Dilemma</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 4, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/whims">whims</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Joe talks about his new business venture, ProCourse! This leads to a conversation about the natural evolution from freelancer to business owner, and all of the challenges that come with it: Setting goals (or choosing not to), getting buried in email, adding yet-another-Slack channel, and telling people IRL what you do in the first place.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/27-the-whole-working-on-the-internet-dilemma/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/whimsthatworklogo.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/48-how-to-win-friends-and-influence-people-by-dale-carnegie/"><h3>48: How to Win Friends and Influence People by Dale Carnegie </h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 30, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It’s time for another classic that both Mike and Joe are a bit embarrassed they haven’t read previously. And it turns out to be a book where the title doesn’t do it justice.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/48-how-to-win-friends-and-influence-people-by-dale-carnegie/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/26-now-somehow-an-employer/"><h3>26: Now Somehow an Employer</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 21, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/whims">whims</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Joe transcends the typical mailbox and gets a UPS box of his own. This leads to a conversation about home offices, which leads to a conversation about wanting to appear legitimate, which leads to an unexpected conversation about learning how to take on new roles.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/26-now-somehow-an-employer/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/whimsthatworklogo.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/47-the-three-big-questions-for-a-frantic-family-by-patrick-lencioni/"><h3>47: The Three Big Questions for a Frantic Family by Patrick Lencioni</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 9, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Should you think about your family in the same way you think about an organization? And what are the ramifications of the answer to that question?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/47-the-three-big-questions-for-a-frantic-family-by-patrick-lencioni/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/25-do-the-work-at-the-beginning/"><h3>25: Do the Work at the Beginning</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 7, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/whims">whims</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Drew has learned from his past mistakes, but is still trying to make everything a bit more optimized. How many times must his desktop overflow before he sets up a file management script or two? Joe shares his own workflows and methods, and the two discuss the ‘work’ that lets you do work more efficiently.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/25-do-the-work-at-the-beginning/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/whimsthatworklogo.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/24-you-had-a-windows-phone/"><h3>24: You Had a Windows Phone?</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 23, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/whims">whims</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Drew has some recording difficulties, which leads to a conversation about redundancy and what happens when something breaks. Joe asks some questions brought about from last week’s conversations, and the two reveal their pre-iPhone hardware stances. Then, Joe goes in-depth on his analog task management set up.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/24-you-had-a-windows-phone/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/whimsthatworklogo.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/46-busy-by-tony-crabbe/"><h3>46: Busy by Tony Crabbe</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 18, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Don’t have time to read books? Then listen to this! Joe and Mike jump into the topic of a busy culture and what we can do about it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/46-busy-by-tony-crabbe/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/23-a-thing-against-printers/"><h3>23: A Thing Against Printers</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 9, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/whims">whims</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>A tech glitch Drew experiences leads to a wide-ranging discussion about tech support, automated cars, and the pros and cons of being an early adopter. Joe is not as convinced about living on the cutting edge.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/23-a-thing-against-printers/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/whimsthatworklogo.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/45-whats-best-next-by-matt-perman/"><h3>45: What’s Best Next by Matt Perman</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 3, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>What does the Bible say about productivity? And how does this book compare to other productivity books?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/45-whats-best-next-by-matt-perman/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/22-a-very-web-developer-solution/"><h3>22: A Very Web Developer Solution</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 26, 2018</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/whims">whims</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Drew has some chair problems. Standing desks are discussed, which (of course) leads to a conversation about the future of iPads. <div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/28-analog-podcasting/"><h3>28: Analog Podcasting</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 20, 2017</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/theoretical">theoretical</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Josh gets fancy with his shaving. And both of them digress on finances and chip cards.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/15-make-the-bad-guy-relatable/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/theoreticallogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

The question is whether or not they can bring themselves to do it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/31-the-power-of-a-positive-no-by-william-ury/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/14-what-comes-first/"><h3>14: What Comes First?</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 13, 2017</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/theoretical">theoretical</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Are Josh and Joe trading places? And how does one go about marketing themselves without coming across as pushy? Also, they want to share more tidbits. And if so, is it worth doing anything about? It’s a tough topic but Mike and Joe work their way through it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/19-the-shallows-by-nicholas-carr/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/17-qbq-the-question-behind-the-question-by-john-miller/"><h3>17: QBQ! The Question Behind The Question by John Miller</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 11, 2017</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It may not be your fault, but you can take responsibility for it. But that still doesn’t stop them from talking checklists and the power they hold.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/16-the-checklist-manifesto-by-atul-gawande/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/top-five-books-from-2016/"><h3>Top Five Books From 2016</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 12, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/books">books</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>In the past I’ve wanted to be a reader and yet never picked up a book. But that changed when I said yes to <a href="http://bookworm.fm">Bookworm</a>. Since then I’ve read 16 books for Bookworm and four more on my own. And I’m on pace to read three more by year’s end.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/top-five-books-from-2016/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/top-five-books-from-2016.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/time-tracker-with-running-status/"><h3>Time Tracker With Running Status</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 9, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/time">time</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve been tracking where I spend my time for a while now. In the majority of cases it has been purely for personal use and decision-making, but since I have now taken a part time IT position, I need to know exactly how many hours I spend on the job and calculate whether or not I’ve met my expected quota for the week.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/time-tracker-with-running-status/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/time-tracker-with-running-status.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/15-brainchains-by-theo-compernolle/"><h3>15: BrainChains by Theo Compernolle</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 7, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>BrainChains was a listener recommendation that taught Mike and Joe a lot about how technology affects our minds. From attention to focus, it’s all covered.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/15-brainchains-by-theo-compernolle/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-a-cloudfront-cdn-for-jekyll-without-s3/"><h3>Using a Cloudfront CDN for Jekyll Without S3</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 5, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/jekyll">jekyll</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>On occasion I find myself with a sliver of free time. And it seems inevitable that I use it to tinker with this site. Given my latest obsession with page load speeds, this time I directed my attention towards the implementation of a CDN.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-a-cloudfront-cdn-for-jekyll-without-s3/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/using-a-cloudfront-cdn-for-jekyll-without-s3.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/a-baby-time-checklist/"><h3>A Baby Time Checklist</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 2, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/checklists">checklists</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>As I write this, my wife and I are expecting our third baby girl to join us within the next week. I wish I could say there is nothing but pure excitement in our house, but as anyone who has kids knows, there are a number of things to do once you know it is “time.” Depending on your situation, which you can’t predetermine, you may not have much time to accomplish everything and get out the door, so most of us put together a checklist to help us remember.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/a-baby-time-checklist/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/a-baby-time-checklist.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/creating-custom-web-searches-in-alfred/"><h3>Creating Custom Web Searches in Alfred</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 28, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/alfred">alfred</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Searching is one of the most technically complicated processes to build and yet the simplest to use. And it’s almost universally accepted that every website has a way to search the entirety of their content. Connect this with the ability to search websites directly from Alfred and you can create a one-stop shop for searching all your favorite sites.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/creating-custom-web-searches-in-alfred/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/creating-custom-web-searches-in-alfred.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-discourse-for-it/"><h3>Using Discourse for IT</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 25, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/communication">communication</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/discourse">discourse</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’m a fan of <a href="http://discourse.org">Discourse</a>. That should come without surprise at this point. As a fan, it’s natural for me to see the potential for Discourse to solve communication problems and create selective visibility within an organization. So it was easy for me to gravitate toward it for the IT communication structure at my church.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-discourse-for-it/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/using-discourse-for-it.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/14-the-12-week-year-by-brian-moran-michael-lennington/"><h3>14: The 12 Week Year by Brian Moran, Michael Lennington</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 23, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>If you’re looking for a way to set goals and achieve a year’s worth of work in 12 weeks, then The 12 Week Year is an excellent choice and structure to try.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/14-the-12-week-year-by-brian-moran-michael-lennington/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/hybrid-productivity/"><h3>Hybrid Productivity</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 21, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/productivity">productivity</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>There’s a common misconception in the productivity world that when you develop a new process or system it needs to be entirely digital or entirely analog. Or the more common version of this dilemma: to work toward the use of a single database for your tasks. That may be nice, but it’s far from necessary.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/hybrid-productivity/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/hybrid-productivity.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/autoarchiving-emails-in-gmail/"><h3>Auto-Archiving Emails in Gmail</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 18, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/email">email</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>In the midst of reading for <a href="http://bookworm.fm">Bookworm</a>, I discovered my habit of quickly checking my email throughout the day. It’s a simple habit on the surface, but try to break it and you’ll find that willpower alone may not be enough to win.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/autoarchiving-emails-in-gmail/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/autoarchiving-emails-in-gmail.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/food-and-productivity-from-a-farm-boy/"><h3>Food and Productivity (From a Farm Boy)</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 14, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/food">food</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>We all need to eat. The consequences of rejecting that fact are far from pleasant and none of us would argue this reality. The problem comes when choosing which foods to consume. It’s not enough that our supermarkets are overflowing and options are endless; we have corporate marketing schemes, dietary standards, and fear mongering to battle.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/food-and-productivity-from-a-farm-boy/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/food-and-productivity-from-a-farm-boy.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/stop-the-should/"><h3>Stop The Should</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 11, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/expectations">expectations</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/fear">fear</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>One of the strongest fears I grapple with is that of rejection. Like most, I want people to appreciate the work I do and me as a person. My struggle develops when I sense a dislike or underappreciation directed towards me in some way. Red flags start flying and I find myself searching for ways to get out of the scenario.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/stop-the-should/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/stop-the-should.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/13-managing-oneself-by-peter-drucker/"><h3>13: Managing Oneself by Peter Drucker</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 9, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>One of the most valuable tasks you can begin is the development of your self-awareness. This week Mike and Joe delve into the questions posed by Peter Drucker that prompt you to learn how to manage yourself.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/13-managing-oneself-by-peter-drucker/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/a-roller-coaster-relationship-with-books/"><h3>A Roller Coaster Relationship With Books</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 7, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/books">books</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I was an avid reader in grade school. Any program the school put in place to encourage kids to read, I completed as fast as I could. That trend continued until I made it to junior high.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/a-roller-coaster-relationship-with-books/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/a-roller-coaster-relationship-with-books.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-the-permanence-of-paper-as-resistance/"><h3>Using The Permanence of Paper as Resistance</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 4, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/analog">analog</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>The concept of resistance is getting to be common knowledge. In its original context as posed by <a href="https://www.amazon.com/War-Art-Through-Creative-Battles/dp/1936891026/ref=sr_1_1?tag=joebuhlig-20">Steven Pressfield</a>, resistance is entirely negative. It is the internal and sometimes external force keeping us from doing our best work. As good brainworkers we consistently look for tactics, methodologies, and habits to remove and eliminate resistance.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-the-permanence-of-paper-as-resistance/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/using-the-permanence-of-paper-as-resistance.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/the-day-on-paper/"><h3>The Day On Paper</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 31, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/analog">analog</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I have tried numerous methods of managing my daily tasks digitally. But no matter the tool or the method, I am unable to replicate the clarity and motivation that comes from using pen and paper to plan and reflect on my day.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/the-day-on-paper/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/the-day-on-paper.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/behind-the-scenes-of-working-with-omnifocus/"><h3>Behind The Scenes Of Working With Omnifocus</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 28, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>More often than not, I find myself surprised by the questions I get after releasing a new script or product. After releasing <a href="https://workingwithomnifocus.com">Working With OmniFocus</a> I received more emails about how the site is set up then I did about the course itself. It’s apparent to me that this is something different that others are interested in. So here’s how I did it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/behind-the-scenes-of-working-with-omnifocus/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/behind-the-scenes-of-working-with-omnifocus.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/12-the-productivity-project-by-chris-bailey/"><h3>12: The Productivity Project by Chris Bailey</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 26, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Mike and Joe get a breath of fresh air with a book on productivity. There are a lot of tips here that they’ve both practiced for years but learned a lot regardless.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/12-the-productivity-project-by-chris-bailey/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/checking-in-on-dvorak/"><h3>Checking In on Dvorak</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 24, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/dvorak">dvorak</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It’s been about 10 months since I <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/dvorak-transition/">switched to Dvorak</a>. It’s been at least six months since I’ve <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/is-dvorak-worth-it/">written about it</a>. In that six months, I have continued to make improvements but I’ve also noticed an interesting tidbit about my relationship with QWERTY.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/checking-in-on-dvorak/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/checking-in-on-dvorak.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/discourse-commenting-for-jekyll/"><h3>Discourse Commenting for Jekyll</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 21, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/discourse">discourse</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/jekyll">jekyll</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>For years, Disqus has been the commenting platform of choice. It’s what I used when my site was on WordPress. When I switched to a static site generated by <a href="http://jekyllrb.com/">Jekyll</a>, I pulled commenting entirely. But given the topics I write about, comments can be quite helpful and I realize that was a mistake. So I brought them back with the help of <a href="http://www.discourse.org/">Discourse</a>.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/discourse-commenting-for-jekyll/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/discourse-commenting-for-jekyll.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/digging-into-alfred-remote/"><h3>Digging Into Alfred Remote</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 17, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/alfred">alfred</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Alfred is a tool I use hundreds of times a day without realizing it. I’m not sure why it took me so long to pick up <a href="https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/alfred-remote/id927944141?mt=8&amp;at=1l3vnyQ">Alfred Remote</a> for my phone, but I’m now seeing the potential for some really advanced triggering for my Mac.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/digging-into-alfred-remote/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/digging-into-alfred-remote.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/converting-drafts-text-to-title-case/"><h3>Converting Drafts Text to Title Case</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 14, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/drafts">drafts</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Drafts is easily one of the most used apps on my phone. To me, it is the pinnacle of resistance-free digital capture. If I look through my list of processed drafts, the most common forms of text I capture are content ideas and book suggestions. This tells me I read, write, and record a lot.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/converting-drafts-text-to-title-case/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/converting-drafts-text-to-title-case.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/11-the-innovators-dilemma-by-clayton-m-christensen/"><h3>11: The Innovator’s Dilemma by Clayton M. Christensen</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 12, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Mike almost put this one down. The business principles discussed are vital but the book itself was a challenge.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/11-the-innovators-dilemma-by-clayton-m-christensen/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/fear-of-the-weekly-review/"><h3>Fear of the Weekly Review</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 10, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/reviews">reviews</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’m all about reviews. I think their value greatly outweighs the time involved and energy expended. Most of the time it’s easy for me to initiate a review and step through its checklist, but there are days when I see a weekly review coming up on the calendar and start dreading it immediately.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/fear-of-the-weekly-review/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/fear-of-the-weekly-review.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/changing-prices-on-everything/"><h3>Changing Prices On… Everything</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 7, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/pricing">pricing</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>One of my most hated tasks is setting the price for a new product. It’s painful and it seems like I can never get it right. The bright side is that I’ve been able to learn a lot in the process and that has led me to a price simplification, effective immediately.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/changing-prices-on-everything/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/changing-prices-on-everything.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/multiple-lines-in-drafts-to-multiple-tasks-in-omnifocus/"><h3>Multiple Lines in Drafts to Multiple Tasks in OmniFocus</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 3, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/drafts">drafts</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>One piece missing in my Drafts actions arsenal was the ability to create a single draft with multiple tasks and send them all to OmniFocus via the new URL schemes. This isn’t something I use often but there are times when it would be useful and can be the difference between capturing everything and missing a vital thought.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/multiple-lines-in-drafts-to-multiple-tasks-in-omnifocus/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/multiple-lines-in-drafts-to-multiple-tasks-in-omnifocus.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/time-for-a-refresh/"><h3>Time For a Refresh</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 30, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/development">development</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>This past weekend my wife was gone on a retreat. That meant I took care of our girls on my own. They go to bed about an hour and a half before I do, and like any self-respecting web developer with an aging web design, I took advantage of the extra free time and made some major changes to the look and feel of my home on the web.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/time-for-a-refresh/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/time-for-a-refresh.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/zen-the-art-of-work/"><h3>Zen & The Art of Work</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 29, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/reviews">reviews</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve always admired the thought and intentionality that Kourosh Dini applies to his methods of working and developing structures that help him accomplish his tasks. So I was excited when he gave me the opportunity to go through his video course, <a href="https://gumroad.com/a/753349747"><em>Zen &amp; The Art of Work</em></a>, prior to its launch. I must say that I think this is his best work to date.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/zen-the-art-of-work/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/zen-the-art-of-work.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/10-start-with-why-by-simon-sinek/"><h3>10: Start With Why by Simon Sinek</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 28, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>This week Mike and Joe talk about the value of finding a “why” in everything we do and what happens when companies start with “how” or “what.”</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/10-start-with-why-by-simon-sinek/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/targeted-omnifocus-templates-with-workflow/"><h3>Targeted OmniFocus Templates With Workflow</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 26, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/workflow">workflow</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve been impressed by the speed of the Omni Group’s release cycles lately. It’s obvious they are hard at work on the automation methods for both iOS and macOS. One of these recent releases introduced the ability to create new projects within a specific folder on iOS.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/targeted-omnifocus-templates-with-workflow/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/targeted-omnifocus-templates-with-workflow.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-gmail-permalinks/"><h3>Using Gmail Permalinks [Video]</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 23, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/email">email</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/video">video</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Earlier this week, I <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/forget-third-party-email-apps/">published an article</a> eluding to my use of Gmail’s permalinks. It sparked a number of unexpected questions about how to get them and how I use them on both macOS and iOS. But rather than write it out, I figured a screencast would help convey the process better.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-gmail-permalinks/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/using-gmail-permalinks.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/forget-third-party-email-apps/"><h3>Forget Third Party Email Apps</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 19, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/email">email</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Folks are quite passionate about the software they use to access their email. I fell in that camp for a while but anymore I just don’t get it. I think that stems from my intent to touch emails only once, keep my inbox as empty as possible, and use a single archive folder for all emails I want to keep.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/forget-third-party-email-apps/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/forget-third-party-email-apps.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/building-systems-you-wont-use/"><h3>Building Systems You Won't Use</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 16, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/systems">systems</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’m always looking for a way to automate a process or develop a structure that removes steps from a frequently repeated task. That’s to be expected since I enjoy the world of productivity and do a fair amount of development.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/building-systems-you-wont-use/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/building-systems-you-wont-use.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/9-daring-greatly-by-brene-brown/"><h3>9: Daring Greatly by Brené Brown</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 14, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>We’re trying a different flavor of book this time and discussing our relationships and feelings with Brené Brown’s Daring Greatly.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/9-daring-greatly-by-brene-brown/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/creating-drafts-actions-in-bulk/"><h3>Creating Drafts Actions In Bulk</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 12, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/drafts">drafts</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When the Omni Group implemented the new <a href="https://discourse.omnigroup.com/t/implementation-details-for-omnifocus-2-14-automation/24179?u=joebuhlig">automation methods in OmniFocus for iOS</a>, I was both excited and worried. I had over 30 actions in Drafts that send text to OmniFocus using background emails as an action method. Switching all of those to use URLs was going to take some time.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/creating-drafts-actions-in-bulk/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/creating-drafts-actions-in-bulk.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/when-deep-work-strikes/"><h3>When Deep Work Strikes</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 9, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/books">books</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>There are a plethora of articles promoting and dissecting the tenants and principles proposed by Cal Newport in his book, <a href="https://www.amazon.com/Deep-Work-Focused-Success-Distracted/dp/1455586692/ref=sr_1_1?tag=joebuhlig-20">Deep Work</a>. That’s what led me to picking it for an <a href="http://bookworm.fm/7/">episode of Bookworm</a>. After implementing my takeaways for about a month, I can see a decided difference in my productivity and effectiveness. It’s what allowed me to release <a href="https://workingwithomnifocus.com">Working With OmniFocus</a> when I did and to develop the depth of detail in those videos.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/when-deep-work-strikes/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/when-deep-work-strikes.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/introducing-the-new-working-with-omnifocus/"><h3>Introducing The New Working With OmniFocus</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 1, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Working With OmniFocus has been recreated in video format!  It’s now available on the new dedicated website: <a href="https://workingwithomnifocus.com">workingwithomnifocus.com</a>.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/introducing-the-new-working-with-omnifocus/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/introducing-the-new-working-with-omnifocus.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/8-the-power-of-full-engagement-by-jim-loehr-tony-schwartz/"><h3>8: The Power of Full Engagement by Jim Loehr, Tony Schwartz</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 31, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When you step out beyond time management you land in the world of energy management. It’s a simple concept that is drastically different for everyone embarking on the journey.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/8-the-power-of-full-engagement-by-jim-loehr-tony-schwartz/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/7-deep-work-by-cal-newport/"><h3>7: Deep Work by Cal Newport</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 17, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Mike has a new Apple device despite his minimizing efforts and Joe has finally done something about his email issue.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/7-deep-work-by-cal-newport/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/a-year-without-extra-screens/"><h3>A Year Without Extra Screens</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 15, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hardware">hardware</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>For the last year I’ve been running my business from a MacBook Pro  and an iPhone.  No iPad. No Watch. And no external monitors.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/a-year-without-extra-screens/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/a-year-without-extra-screens.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/information-overwhelm-without-the-internet/"><h3>Information Overwhelm Without The Internet</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 12, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/internet">internet</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I hear people refer to information overwhelm more often than I would expect. The context varies but the idea is the same: finding information on the internet is so easy that the person has a hard time deciphering what is right and what to question. Some even take it as far as to suggest <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2008/07/is-google-making-us-stupid/306868/">Google is making us dumb</a>.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/information-overwhelm-without-the-internet/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/information-overwhelm-without-the-internet.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/woodworking-versus-websites/"><h3>Woodworking Versus Websites</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 8, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/development">development</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/woodworking">woodworking</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>One of the most difficult aspects of building websites or doing knowledge work full-time is the lack of motivation and pride that typically comes from physically seeing the work of your hands. Yes, it is possible to achieve this sense of accomplishment when working purely with information and computers, but it’s far from natural.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/woodworking-versus-websites/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/woodworking-versus-websites.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/moving-omnifocus-scripts-to-ios/"><h3>Moving OmniFocus Scripts To iOS</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 5, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/applescripts">applescripts</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I have been hesitant to adopt the <a href="https://discourse.omnigroup.com/t/implementation-details-for-omnifocus-2-14-automation/24179?u=joebuhlig">new automation methods in OmniFocus</a> for iOS. The abilities of the new URL Scheme are exciting but there’s still quite a bit missing from the structure as it stands.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/moving-omnifocus-scripts-to-ios/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/moving-omnifocus-scripts-to-ios.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/6-the-more-of-less-by-joshua-becker/"><h3>6: The More Of Less by Joshua Becker</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 3, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>This week Mike and Joe talk about cutting back and simplifying life with Joshua Becker’s book <em>The More Of Less</em>.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/6-the-more-of-less-by-joshua-becker/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/too-much-tech/"><h3>Too Much Tech?</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 1, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/devices">devices</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>One of the common threads in the books we’ve read for <a href="http://bookworm.fm">Bookworm</a> is the impact of computers on our effectiveness, self-control, and overall happiness in life. Their prevalence and ubiquity in our world coupled with the newness and speed of their adoption has a lot of us wondering and speculating about the positives and negatives of this shift. So I would expect any book written in the last decade to incorporate thoughts on the topic.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/too-much-tech/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/too-much-tech.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/embracing-the-new-textexpander/"><h3>Embracing The New TextExpander</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 29, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/textexpander">textexpander</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When <a href="https://smilesoftware.com/">Smile</a> introduced the new “Snippet As A Service” version of TextExpander, there was quite an outcry. To be completely honest, I was confused by and resistant to the change at the onset. However, if I look at the new version without allowing my previous experience to color my opinion, it is striking how similar it is to my other choices for software.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/embracing-the-new-textexpander/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/embracing-the-new-textexpander.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/5-essentialism-by-greg-mckeown/"><h3>5: Essentialism by Greg McKeown</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 27, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Joe gets too much email, Mike thinks he should hide his email address, and they both have an interest in saying “no” more often.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/5-essentialism-by-greg-mckeown/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/leaving-pocket-for-instapaper/"><h3>Leaving Pocket For Instapaper</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 25, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/instapaper">instapaper</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/pocket">pocket</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I follow specific websites less and less. I’m more inclined to follow people and services on Twitter and <a href="https://medium.com/@JoeBuhlig">Medium</a> that act as sources of curated articles. This gives me the ability to find sites I normally would have glossed over and still read my favorite writers.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/leaving-pocket-for-instapaper/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/leaving-pocket-for-instapaper.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/updates-for-working-with-omnifocus/"><h3>Updates For Working With OmniFocus</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 22, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It’s been about nine months since I released <em>Working With OmniFocus</em>. A lot has happened in that time and my systems around OmniFocus have morphed quite a bit. Throw in a pile of learning accrued from other projects and I have decided to make some significant changes to the book.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/updates-for-working-with-omnifocus/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/base/WorkingWithOmniFocus-Small.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/4-the-obstacle-is-the-way-by-ryan-holiday/"><h3>4: The Obstacle Is The Way by Ryan Holiday</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 20, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>We all deal with something painful in our lives. And although they are hard to talk about, it’s these obstacles that strengthen us for the future.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/4-the-obstacle-is-the-way-by-ryan-holiday/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>
