<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/textexpander-and-omnifocus/"><h3>TextExpander And OmniFocus</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 18, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/textexpander">textexpander</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>TextExpander and OmniFocus are <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/first-apps-on-a-new-mac/">two of the first tools</a> I install on any new device, so it’s no surprise that the two work well together. You may expect some kind of Applescripting or shell magic, but I keep this extremely simple and only use true text expansion with OmniFocus. I run the scripts manually or behind the scenes with Hazel.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/textexpander-and-omnifocus/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/textexpander-and-omnifocus.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/my-current-home-screen/"><h3>My Current Home Screen</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 15, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/iOS">iOS</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When I <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/the-overwhelm-inbox/">consolidated a handful of my inboxes</a> into my email it made me rethink my home screen. I had previously kept it slim but this takes it a step further and creates significant resistance to activities better left undone.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/my-current-home-screen/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/my-current-home-screen.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/43/"><h3>43: Big Project Decisions</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 14, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/projects">projects</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I have a lot going on with a number of new projects taking off. But with new doors opening, a few doors need to be closed.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/43/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Big-Project-Decisions.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/3-the-war-of-art-by-steven-pressfield/"><h3>3: The War Of Art by Steven Pressfield</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 13, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Whether it’s writing or building a business, we all struggle to put in the work to create. Mike and Joe discuss going pro with their art and overcoming resistance.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/3-the-war-of-art-by-steven-pressfield/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/working-with-ideas-now-open/"><h3>Working With Ideas: Now Open</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 12, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/course">course</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Our ability to come up with ideas is like a muscle. If we work on it and develop the right habits, we get stronger and have more options available to us. But it’s difficult to build muscle if you don’t understand “how” the muscle works and the mechanics behind its improvement. Getting ideas is challenging until you learn what they are and how they work.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/working-with-ideas-now-open/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/introducing-working-with-ideas.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/mindsets-before-tools/"><h3>Mindsets Before Tools</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 11, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/mindsets">mindsets</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Every time I come across an article that compares applications or declares an app to be the best at something, I cringe. Very few of them explain the scenarios necessary to make their conclusion valid.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/mindsets-before-tools/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/mindsets-before-tools.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/2-the-willpower-instinct-by-kelly-mcgonigal/"><h3>2: The Willpower Instinct by Kelly McGonigal</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 9, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Whether it’s overcoming an addiction to email or sticking to a diet, The Willpower Instinct is excellent at helping you develop the self-control to accomplish your goals.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/2-the-willpower-instinct-by-kelly-mcgonigal/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/1-getting-things-done-by-david-allen/"><h3>1: Getting Things Done by David Allen</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 8, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Welcome to Bookworm! To kick things off, we’ve reread a book we both rely on heavily in our lives, Getting Things Done by David Allen. This is the best discussion either of us have had about GTD in a long time.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/1-getting-things-done-by-david-allen/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/a-new-podcast-bookworm/"><h3>A New Podcast: Bookworm</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 7, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/bookworm">bookworm</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Almost 2 months ago I embarked on a journey of reading a book every two weeks. Although there are a lot of personal benefits to doing this, it is primarily for a new podcast I’m doing with my good friend, <a href="http://mikeschmitz.me/">Mike Schmitz</a>.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/a-new-podcast-bookworm/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/bookwormlogo.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/my-podcasting-setup/"><h3>My Podcasting Setup</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 27, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/podcasting">podcasting</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I have detailed <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/the-science-and-experience-of-analog-writing/">my writing process</a> quite a bit lately, but that made me realize I have never pulled all the pieces of my podcasting setup together. Let’s change that.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/my-podcasting-setup/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/my-podcasting-setup.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/time-for-books/"><h3>Time For Books</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 24, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/books">books</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>In order to read a book every two weeks (and sometimes every week) I have had to make reading a practice that is incorporated throughout my day. Having a single time for reading isn’t enough and it has become a ritual I like to incorporate as many places as I can.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/time-for-books/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/time-for-books.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/42/"><h3>42: Deciding On A Medium</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 22, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/mediums">mediums</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>If you create content in any form and have dabbled in multiple mediums, you’re left with a decision about which method of consumption is best for the topic you want to present.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/42/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Deciding-On-A-Medium.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/introducing-working-with-ideas/"><h3>Introducing Working With Ideas</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 21, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/course">course</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>There are times when you realize a project needs to take a hard turn. Your original intent is good, but it doesn’t accomplish your goal as well as it might.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/introducing-working-with-ideas/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/introducing-working-with-ideas.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/an-open-letter-to-productivity/"><h3>An Open Letter To Productivity</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 20, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/productivity">productivity</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>My friend,</p><p>We’ve come a long way since we met five years ago. And I cannot thank you enough for the clarity and direction you’ve given me through the multiple transitions and big decisions I have faced in recent years. Without the systems and tricks you’ve taught me, I would accomplish much less and fall short of numerous goals. For that, I am grateful.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/an-open-letter-to-productivity/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/an-open-letter-to-productivity.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/reading-books-on-a-schedule/"><h3>Reading Books On A Schedule</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 17, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/books">books</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>For years I have wanted to read more books. Prolific readers rave about the benefits and world-renowned leaders often attribute their ideas and successes to their habit of reading, but to me the benefits of having read a lot of books  was secondary to the innate sense that a realm of knowledge and experience was available to me, but I was missing it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/reading-books-on-a-schedule/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/reading-books-on-a-schedule.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/41/"><h3>41: Fountain Pens</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 15, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hardware">hardware</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’m pushing pen addict status. I don’t think I’m there yet, but I do have three fountain pens that I thoroughly enjoy using.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/41/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Fountain-Pens.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/the-deception-of-working-on-a-system/"><h3>The Deception of Working on a System</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 13, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/systems">systems</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It’s a trap so easy to fall for: we find ourselves spending multiple hours fine-tuning, tweaking, and developing the simple structure that will automatically create more time and 3X our daily productivity.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/the-deception-of-working-on-a-system/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/the-deception-of-working-on-a-system.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/analog-writing-organization/"><h3>Analog Writing Organization</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 10, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/writing">writing</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When I made the decision to <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/the-science-and-experience-of-analog-writing/">embrace pen and paper</a>, the need for structure quickly showed its face. I wanted my writing to live in a single notebook, but that meant I needed a method of tracking progress on pieces without thumbing through the whole notebook.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/analog-writing-organization/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/analog-writing-organization.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/40/"><h3>40: The Problem With Audiobooks</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 8, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/books">books</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I sometimes listen to books via audio but there are a couple flaws with audiobooks that have me avoiding them when I can.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/40/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/The-Problem-With-Audiobooks.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/the-overwhelm-inbox/"><h3>The Overwhelm Inbox</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 6, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/inbox">inbox</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>The purpose of my <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/inbox-consolidation/">inbox consolidation project</a> is to cut back on the number of places I go to make decisions about my “open loops”. Between feeds, social media, and our always-on expectations, it becomes a habit and struggle to keep up with the mass of apps and information thrown at us. My theory was to create an aggregated inbox via email that combines these potentially overwhelming sources of inputs. The hope was to build a system that helps me scale back on the time and impulse to repeatedly process these inboxes.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/the-overwhelm-inbox/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/the-overwhelm-inbox.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/editorial-as-a-database-viewer/"><h3>Editorial As A Database Viewer</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 3, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>One habit that Evernote taught me was that of creating databases, collections of text and pictures that revolve around a specific topic or item. I’m yet to export my Evernote data into my <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/an-alternative-to-evernote/">alternative storage system</a> but I have solved my most glaring issue: searching and viewing these databases on iOS.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/editorial-as-a-database-viewer/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/editorial-as-a-database-viewer.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/39/"><h3>39: Morning and Evening Rituals</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 1, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/rituals">rituals</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>What you do for your morning and evening rituals doesn’t have to match what others do. The top 10 things that highly successful people do in the morning may derail your day entirely.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/39/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Morning-and-Evening-Rituals.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/checklists-in-omnifocus/"><h3>Checklists in OmniFocus</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 30, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Keeping different types of information in separate apps or systems is sometimes worth the extra infrastructure. But there is also a lot of value and mental freedom in using an existing process for multiple forms of data.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/checklists-in-omnifocus/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/checklists-in-omnifocus.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/inbox-consolidation/"><h3>Inbox Consolidation</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 27, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>As part of a new project that will be released in a few weeks, I recently reread <em>Getting Things Done</em> by David Allen. I found it interesting that David hasn’t changed his tune when it comes to information overload. Despite a dramatic increase in technology and the volume of inputs as compared to the original writing, he still advocates for the same capture mechanisms and clarification process.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/inbox-consolidation/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/inbox-consolidation.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/38/"><h3>38: Using Multiple Desks In One Office</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 25, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hardware">hardware</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Since starting to exclusively write with pen and paper, I’ve added a dedicated writing desk to my office. This week I explore the pros and cons of using multiple desks in my office.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/38/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Using-Multiple-Desks-In-One-Office.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/intentional-gtd-titles/"><h3>Intentional GTD Titles</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 23, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When I started with GTD five years ago, I was certain it was the missing piece to my mental overwhelm puzzle. It was the five-step framework that would keep me from procrastinating and give me the motivation to accomplish everything to which I kept saying yes.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/intentional-gtd-titles/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/intentional-gtd-titles.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/the-science-and-experience-of-analog-writing/"><h3>The Science and Experience of Analog Writing</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 20, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/writing">writing</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I began <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/writing-articles-by-hand/">hand writing articles</a> with a lot of skepticism mixed with hope. I didn’t know what to expect but I wanted a positive outcome. As much as I lean toward an integration of technology in every aspect of my work, I felt a sense that paper had benefits I had never understood.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/the-science-and-experience-of-analog-writing/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/the-science-and-experience-of-analog-writing.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/guest-posting/"><h3>Guest Posting</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 18, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/meta">meta</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Over the past month I’ve made some design changes and layout alterations here on the site. Some of that was purely for aesthetics and ease of use, but it also included some back-end alterations to allow guest posting. I’ve debated this for a long time and I’m finally ready to pull the trigger.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/guest-posting/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/guest-posting.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/37/"><h3>37: Reading Books vs Articles</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 18, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/adhd">adhd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/books">books</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>As I learn how to handle the good and bad that comes from being ADHD, I’ve learned the power of reading books over articles.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/37/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/reading-books-vs-articles.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/alternating-types-of-tasks/"><h3>Alternating Types of Tasks</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 16, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/tasks">tasks</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>There’s something liberating about putting a name to something you didn’t understand. This was my exact experience when I learned I am ADHD. It gave me words to explain the way I think and those words have given way to a deeper comprehension of how I operate.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/alternating-types-of-tasks/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/alternating-types-of-tasks.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/what-to-review/"><h3>What To Review</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 13, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/reviews">reviews</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>The longer I practice GTD principles, the more intentional I try to be with the time I spend updating my systems. I need my commitments to be thought through and my decisions to be made ahead of time. Knowing that I am prone to starting new projects before I have time for them leads me to a need for a recurring time of reevaluation.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/what-to-review/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/what-to-review.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/36/"><h3>36: My Current GTD Structure</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 11, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It’s been a while since I’ve shared my entire GTD structure. And now that I’m rereading the book, I figured it would be a good idea to share what I’m currently doing before it changes.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/36/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/My-Current-GTD-Structure.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/hazel-keeping-omnifocus-updated/"><h3>Hazel Keeping OmniFocus Updated</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 9, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hazel">hazel</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>There are times when you need a feature in software that doesn’t currently exist. Sometimes that leads to exploring alternatives or even creating your own, which is how inventors and entrepreneurs get a lot of their ideas.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/hazel-keeping-omnifocus-updated/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/hazel-keeping-omnifocus-updated.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/writing-articles-by-hand/"><h3>Writing Articles By Hand</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 6, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/writing">writing</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>After reflecting on the process of <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/22/">writing a daily schedule by hand</a> and discussing <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/33/">the benefits of the analog over the digital</a>, I’ve decided to try writing articles with pen and paper.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/writing-articles-by-hand/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/writing-articles-by-hand.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/35/"><h3>35: Why I'm Into Productivity</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 4, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/productivity">productivity</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve been actively exploring why I am big into productivity for the past two months. In part, that led me to seeing a counselor and discovering a missing piece to my mental puzzle, even though it’s likely obvious to most.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/35/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Why-I'm-Into-Productivity.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/creating-a-personal-book-index/"><h3>Creating a Personal Book Index</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 2, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/reading">reading</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I used to just pick up a book, start at the beginning, and read it to the end. I tried not to bend any pages and always used a bookmark to make sure the book still looked brand new when I was finished. I had an unwarranted fear of ruining my books because I held them in such high regard.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/creating-a-personal-book-index/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Creating-a-Personal-Book-Index.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/is-dvorak-worth-it/"><h3>Is Dvorak Worth It?</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 29, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/dvorak">dvorak</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>After almost three months of typing with a <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/dvorak-transition/">Dvorak keyboard</a>, I’ve reached some conclusions about this QWERTY alternative. Like most comparisons of this nature there are some significant pros and cons between the two. But I don’t think it’s fair to draw any conclusions until you’ve experienced both sides.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/is-dvorak-worth-it/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Is-Dvorak-Worth-It.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/34/"><h3>34: A Web Developer Using Markdown</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 27, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/writing">writing</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Markdown has become a major part of how I do all of my writing despite being a web developer. It has a lot of benefits even if you know how to write the HTML itself.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/34/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/A-Web-Developer-Using-Markdown.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-the-analog-to-grasp-the-digital/"><h3>Using the Analog to Grasp the Digital</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 25, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/analog">analog</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/digital">digital</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’m guilty of looking for ways to accomplish tasks on the computer long before it crosses my mind to try paper or the whiteboard. It’s almost embarrassing sometimes. The idea of going to a notepad as a first instinct is hard for me to grasp.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-the-analog-to-grasp-the-digital/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Using-the-Analog-to-Grasp-the-Digital.jpeg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/the-omnifocus-dashboard/"><h3>The OmniFocus Dashboard</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 22, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I write and talk about my OmniFocus Dashboard a lot. And that’s for good reason: it’s the central hub of my day-to-day work and the place where my decisions about the day surface.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/the-omnifocus-dashboard/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/The-OmniFocus-Dashboard.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/33/"><h3>33: Analog vs. Digital with Mike Schmitz</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 20, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/analog">analog</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/digital">digital</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Mike Schmitz joins me this week to talk through the use of analog tools and how that can help us understand when and where to use the appropriate digital tool.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/33/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Analog-vs-Digital-with-Mike-Schmitz.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/the-flawed-foundation-of-diets/"><h3>The Flawed Foundation of Diets</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 18, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/food">food</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>After working on multiple sides of agriculture and seeing how the back-end of the food industry operates, I’ve come to the realization that there is some really bad information out there about agriculture and how we decide what to eat.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/the-flawed-foundation-of-diets/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/the-flawed-foundation-of-diets.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/evernote-vs-raw-files/"><h3>Evernote vs. Raw Files</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 15, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/evernote">evernote</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Ever since I published an <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/an-alternative-to-evernote/">article about leaving Evernote</a> I’ve received numerous recommendations for alternatives. It seems there is an endless supply of catchall buckets that you can drop information into.  I appreciate all the ideas, but it isn’t the point.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/evernote-vs-raw-files/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Evernote-vs-Raw-Files.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/32/"><h3>32: Doing the Task Shuffle</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 13, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/ideas">ideas</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/tasks">tasks</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Here’s an update on the new TextExpander pricing and a deep dive into why I wrote a script that shuffles my tasks. That’s right. There’s a big benefit to randomizing a task list.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/32/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Doing-the-Task-Shuffle.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/the-important-not-urgent-projects/"><h3>The Important (Not Urgent) Projects</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 11, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/projects">projects</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>We all have those projects that we <em>know</em> we should be working on, but without a deadline or someone relying on you it’s hard to keep it going. Things come up and the easy tasks to put off are the ones without urgency pushing them on.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/the-important-not-urgent-projects/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/The-important-not-urgent-projects.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/and-now/"><h3>And Now...</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 8, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/meta">meta</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I ran across this idea when reading an article by <a href="https://sivers.org/">Derek Sivers</a>. The premise is simple: creating a frequently updated page to show what the person is currently doing. The concept really resonated with me, and I expanded on it a bit.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/and-now/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/And-Now.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/31/"><h3>31: Apps, Websites, and TextExpander Pricing</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 6, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/development">development</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/textexpander">textexpander</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I go on a rant about building websites instead of apps. That leads me to a subsidiary rant about the polarizing changes to TextExpander.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/31/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Apps-Websites-and-TextExpander-Pricing.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/timing-tasks/"><h3>Timing Tasks</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 4, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/productivity">productivity</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>In a previous role I spent some time researching project management software and evaluating it for company use. One of the turn-offs that my end users brought up was an extreme distaste for running a stopwatch on the tasks being tracked. I get it. No one wants to be stuck to a clock, especially when those reviewing the numbers are your managers.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/timing-tasks/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Timing-Tasks.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/a-text-file-weather-forecast/"><h3>A Text File Weather Forecast</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 1, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/text-files">text-files</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/weather">weather</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It never fails. I sit at our kitchen table over breakfast and mention to my wife that it’s going to snow that day. The first question she asks? <em>“How much?”</em> I don’t know! All I know is that my alert says it’s supposed to happen!</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/a-text-file-weather-forecast/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/A-Text-File-Weather-Forececast.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/30/"><h3>30: Decision Analysis Paralysis</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 30, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/contexts">contexts</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/tasks">tasks</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When you have a large amount of data available, it’s easy to be paralyzed in making a decision about how to analyze it. The same is true when you have a lot of tasks and little clarity.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/30/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Decision-Analysis-Paralysis.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/choosing-omnifocus-settings/"><h3>Choosing OmniFocus Settings</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 28, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>No application setup is complete without tweaking the settings to your liking. This is the power (and struggle) of OmniFocus. Some of the available options make drastic changes while others lead to subtleties you may not notice.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/choosing-omnifocus-settings/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Choosing-OmniFocus-Settings.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/a-record-of-completed-tasks/"><h3>A Record of Completed Tasks</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 25, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/applescripts">applescripts</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hazel">hazel</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/text-files">text-files</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>There are times when I want to look back and see what I did on a specific day. This is extremely helpful when I need a record for a client, but no matter the reason, I find myself referring to my task history frequently.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/a-record-of-completed-tasks/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/A-Record-of-Completed-Tasks.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/29/"><h3>29: Get Started and Iterate</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 23, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/development">development</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>In this episode, I go through the ideas behind agile development and applying them to get a minimum viable product out the door. This is exactly how OmniGroup has now gotten to the point of bringing themes back to OmniFocus. Oh, and I completely missed daylight savings.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/29/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Get-Started-and-Iterate.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/alfred-theme/"><h3>A Minimal Alfred Theme</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 22, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/alfred">alfred</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve got a bonus for you this week: my Alfred theme. I’ve tweaked the look of Alfred quite a bit over the few years I’ve been using it. I wanted something simple and unobtrusive, but I also wanted it to be compact and cram a lot of data into a small space. If that sounds appealing, give it a try.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/alfred-theme/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/A-Minimal-Alfred-Theme.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/favorite-alfred-tricks/"><h3>Favorite Alfred Tricks</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 21, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/alfred">alfred</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>My Mac is useless without <a href="https://www.alfredapp.com/">Alfred</a>. That’s no joke. I try to use my wife’s profile once in a while. It’s painful for me and hilarious for her to watch. I keep hitting the Alfred shortcuts and staring at it like it’s broken.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/favorite-alfred-tricks/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Favorite-Alfred-Tricks.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/text-file-setup-and-workflow/"><h3>Text File Setup and Workflow</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 18, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/setups">setups</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/text-files">text-files</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Now that I’ve moved <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/an-alternative-to-evernote/">away from Evernote</a>, the primary way I store information is through text files. It’s taken me a while to get it nailed down but I’ve managed to simplify the number of apps I use and the flow of text across my devices.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/text-file-setup-and-workflow/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Text-File-Setup-and-Workflow.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/28/"><h3>28: Why Is Focus So Hard?</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 16, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/focus">focus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve slowly drifted away from the mission that gets me excited each day. And that’s due to a lack of focus and alignment with my goals.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/28/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Why-Is-Focus-So-Hard.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/choosing-the-right-medium/"><h3>Choosing the Right Medium</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 14, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/communication">communication</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>You’re reading them right now. And the medium that they arrive in will change their weight. Words. Words in email have less impact than a handwritten letter. And a conversation over coffee has more sway than a phone call.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/choosing-the-right-medium/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Choosing-the-Right-Medium.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/behind-the-scenes/"><h3>Behind The Scenes</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 11, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/setups">setups</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Almost daily, I get an email from someone interested in how I have this site set up. “It’s not WordPress and Disqus. What are you using?” We can talk about that, but why not take it a few steps further? Let’s go from domain registrar to the reader.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/behind-the-scenes/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Behind-the-Scenes.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/27/"><h3>27: Pit of Procrastination</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 9, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/dvorak">dvorak</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/procrastination">procrastination</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I reflect on my tendencies to fall into a procrastination pit. And a reader emailed me about web designers posing as developers so I go off on a rant.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/27/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Pit-of-Procrastination.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-gtd-as-a-woodworker/"><h3>Using GTD As A Woodworker</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 7, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Hobbies are great candidates for GTD. With all the commitments we tend to take on, free time to spend on our hobbies can be elusive. That means it’s helpful to have a system in place that keeps track of where we were and what comes next.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-gtd-as-a-woodworker/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Using-GTD-as-a-Woodworker.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-gtd-as-a-man/"><h3>Using GTD As A Man</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 4, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>To be honest, I struggled with this article. I wanted to write it but wasn’t sure how to convey what I was thinking. GTD has helped me as a man more than I realized but the impact has been implicit, not obvious.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-gtd-as-a-man/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Using-GTD-as-a-Man.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/26/"><h3>26: The Value of Lurking</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 2, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/discussions">discussions</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/lurking">lurking</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Let’s talk about lurkers. Well, I’ll talk about them. You can just listen. And that’s okay because there’s a lot of value in lurking.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/26/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/The-Value-of-Lurking.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-gtd-as-a-dad/"><h3>Using GTD As A Dad</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 29, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>One of the greatest things a dad will ever hear is the sound of his kids squealing in joy while they play games together. It’s energizing and pure pleasure to see the delight and sparkle in their eyes as they ask to “do it again!” Those are the memories that we hope to multiply.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-gtd-as-a-dad/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Using-GTD-as-a-Dad.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-gtd-as-a-husband/"><h3>Using GTD As A Husband</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 26, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I find it easy to let my marriage slide. We love each other so it should come naturally, right? Roses every Valentine’s, daily love notes, and genuine conversations each night. If that’s second-nature to you, I envy you.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-gtd-as-a-husband/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Using-GTD-as-a-Husband.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/25/"><h3>25: Creating Ideas</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 24, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/ideas">ideas</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Coming up with ideas doesn’t have to be hard. There are four ways I create new ideas. And I had a moment of insight about being content at a birthday party for our girls.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/25/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Creating-Ideas.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-gtd-as-a-writer/"><h3>Using GTD As A Writer</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 22, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It never fails. I’ll be mowing the lawn or riding my bike and that’s when it hits me. There’s nothing I can do about it. I wish it would leave me alone until I could do something about it, but there I am; trying to figure out how I’m going to write those lines down.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-gtd-as-a-writer/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Using-GTD-as-a-Writer.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-gtd-as-a-homeowner/"><h3>Using GTD As A Homeowner</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 19, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Most of the time when I’m discussing GTD with a friend or online it’s in the context of getting more work done more efficiently. I agree that this is the easy target for the framework; our jobs and the work we do each day are the most pressing and stressing in our lives. We need as much help as we can get to stay on top of it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-gtd-as-a-homeowner/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Using-GTD-as-a-Homeowner.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/24/"><h3>24: No More Project Codes</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 17, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/dvorak">dvorak</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/evernote">evernote</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>With my recent move away from Evernote, I’ve made the decision to leave my project codes behind. And although there are serious competitors to Evernote, I’m staying away from them.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/24/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/No-More-Project-Codes.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/the-value-of-tradition/"><h3>The Value of Tradition</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 15, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Having young kids has made us think consciously about the traditions we want to pass down to them. What do we want them to learn? Will our traditions help them see the importance of our view of the world? Are they fun?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/the-value-of-tradition/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/The-Value-of-Tradition.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/an-alternative-to-evernote/"><h3>An Alternative to Evernote</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 12, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/evernote">evernote</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve been a supporter of Evernote for a long time. I’ve written a number of articles on it and convinced a number of friends and family to start using it. But I’ve run into some issues with it and it’s come time to throw in the towel. I’m leaving Evernote.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/an-alternative-to-evernote/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/An-alternative-to-Evernote.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/23/"><h3>23: White Space</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 10, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apple">apple</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/margin">margin</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Leaving space around the edges of your day can have a major impact on your productivity and happiness throughout the day. Also, I’m glad I don’t have an Apple Watch.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/23/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/White-Space.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/how-to-create-energizing-rituals/"><h3>How to Create Energizing Rituals</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 8, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/energy">energy</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/rituals">rituals</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I learned about creating rituals after I read <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/power-full-engagement-book-review/">The Power of Full Engagement</a> over a year ago. Since that time I’ve been figuring a few things out about building and implementing energizing rituals.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/how-to-create-energizing-rituals/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/How-to-Create-Energizing-Rituals.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/budgeting-and-irregular-expenses/"><h3>Budgeting and Irregular Expenses</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 5, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/budget">budget</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>You’re cruising along and your bank account is looking good. But then, surprise! You get the bill for your car insurance premium and everything is out the window.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/budgeting-and-irregular-expenses/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Budgeting-and-Irregular-Expenses.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/22/"><h3>22: Addiction to Numbers</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 2, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/addiction">addiction</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Since I started my business I’ve developed an addiction to checking numbers. But I watched a webinar last week that really changed the game for me and has me hand writing my schedule for the day.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/22/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Addiction-to-Numbers.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/the-importance-of-data-visualizations/"><h3>The Importance of Data Visualizations</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 1, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/data">data</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/visualization">visualization</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It’s easy to present data in a summarized table, but what about turning it into a data visualization?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/the-importance-of-data-visualizations/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/The-Importance-of-Data-Visualization.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/time-and-dollars/"><h3>Time and Dollars</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 29, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/budget">budget</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/time">time</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When I started my business, I wasn’t in a place to say no to anything. I needed to provide an income, and every little bit helped. But recently I’ve had to start deciding which activities are most worth my time and which ones need to be put aside.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/time-and-dollars/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Time-and-dollars.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/21/"><h3>21: Issues with Evernote</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 27, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/dvorak">dvorak</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/evernote">evernote</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve found that I have a lot of reasons to leave Evernote. In this episode, I talk through those and give a few updates to the articles I’ve written recently.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/21/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Issues-with-Evernote.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/tracking-time-with-launch-center-pro/"><h3>Tracking Time with Launch Center Pro</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 25, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/ifttt">ifttt</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/launch-center">launch-center</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Lately I’ve been tracking my time and starting to correlate it with dollars earned. The idea is to help me decide which types of work are the most valuable. This is a look at how I’m doing the time tracking portion using <a href="http://contrast.co/launch-center-pro/">Launch Center Pro</a>.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/tracking-time-with-launch-center-pro/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Tracking-time-with-launch-center-pro.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/a-new-discussion/"><h3>A New Discussion</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 22, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/discussions">discussions</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It’s time. I’ve been talking about starting a new community for a couple weeks now and we are moving forward.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/a-new-discussion/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/A-new-discussion.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/20/"><h3>20: Code Freeze</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 20, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/discussions">discussions</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/dvorak">dvorak</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>My Dvorak typing speed is picking up and I’ll be launching a new discussion in two days. Once that’s out, I’ll be going on a code freeze.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/20/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Code-Freeze.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/just-a-laptop/"><h3>Just a Laptop</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 18, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hardware">hardware</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When I started my business I made the shift from three 27” monitors to just a laptop screen. That shift has taught me a few things about how I work.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/just-a-laptop/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Just-a-Laptop.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>
