<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/dictating-vs-typing/"><h3>Dictating vs Typing</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 15, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/dictation">dictation</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/writing">writing</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Dictation is becoming more and more commonplace, and as the software behind it continues to get better we’ll likely see it become a bigger part of our daily lives.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/dictating-vs-typing/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Dictating-vs-Typing.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/19/"><h3>19: Online Discussions</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 13, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/discussions">discussions</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/dvorak">dvorak</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/masterminds">masterminds</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’m looking for a good way to promote online discussions. I share my idea about it and give an update on Dvorak. And what about masterminds?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/19/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Online-Discussions.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/mac-navigation/"><h3>Mac Navigation</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 11, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/alfred">alfred</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/mac">mac</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Nerdy Mac users are known for customizing their machines. Between keyboard shortcuts, Spaces, and third-party apps, you can effectively set up a computer that is perfect for you and unusable by someone else.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/mac-navigation/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Mac-Navigation.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/dvorak-transition/"><h3>Dvorak Transition</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 8, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/dvorak">dvorak</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hardware">hardware</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve had an interest in the Dvorak keyboard layout for a couple years now. The concept makes sense to me and I’m finally doing something about it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/dvorak-transition/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Dvorak-Transition.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/18/"><h3>18: Cold Turkey on QWERTY</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 6, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/dvorak">dvorak</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hardware">hardware</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>After an awesome break for Christmas and the New Year, I’m back with a slight change and format to talk about my switch to Dvorak, the bloated web, and resolutions.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/18/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Cold-Turkey-on-QWERTY.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/2015-by-the-numbers/"><h3>2015 by the Numbers</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 5, 2016</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/reviews">reviews</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>With 2015 completed, we’ll start seeing numbers roll in summarizing what happened throughout the year. So I thought I would pull together this site’s numbers for 2015. It’s been a ride.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/2015-by-the-numbers/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/2015-by-the-Numbers.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/writing-a-book-with-github/"><h3>Writing a Book with GitHub</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 28, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/book">book</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/github">github</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/writing">writing</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>A lot of time and effort go into writing a book. It gets even harder when you need to collaborate with your editor and make revisions.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/writing-a-book-with-github/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Writing-a-Book-with-GitHub.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/trust-let-loose/"><h3>Trust & Let Loose</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 25, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/trust">trust</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/systems">systems</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It takes time to develop consistency in a task management system. I forget. I climb back on the horse, but fall off again. It looks easy - and it is at times - but other times it feels like one more item on my to-do list.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/trust-let-loose/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Trust-and-Let-Loose.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/17/"><h3>17: Time Off for the Holidays</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 23, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/breaks">breaks</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Take time off this holiday season. And try not to spend too much time doing support for family. Also, don’t miss out on the discount for <em>Working with OmniFocus</em>.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/17/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Time-Off-for-the-Holidays.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/bad-bar-charts/"><h3>Bad Bar Charts</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 21, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/charts">charts</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/data">data</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>In previous roles I worked on data analysis and visualization. When you boil it down, that just means I was well versed in Excel and building charts.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/bad-bar-charts/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Bad-Bar-Charts.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/christmas-2015/"><h3>Merry Christmas</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 18, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/christmas">christmas</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/discounts">discounts</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’m thrilled to give you a gift for Christmas this year. I’ve wanted to do something like this for a long time and the opportunity is finally here.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/christmas-2015/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Merry-Christmas-2015.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/16/"><h3>16: Geofenced Lists</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 16, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/lists">lists</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Location based lists have a lot of uses. In this episode, I talk about the main ways I use them and how they’ve helped me in the past. There’s also some follow-up to my time tracking mechanism.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/16/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Geofenced-Lists.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/monthly-planning/"><h3>Monthly Planning</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 14, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/goals">goals</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/reviews">reviews</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>We’re sneaking up on the annual goal setting push. It’s exciting to sit down and dream about what you want to do next year. But what if your life moves and changes too fast for annual goals?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/monthly-planning/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Monthly-Planning.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/textexpander-snippet-nomenclature/"><h3>TextExpander Snippet Nomenclature</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 11, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/textexpander">textexpander</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I currently have 217 snippets in TextExpander. That’s likely not a big number for some people, but for my forgetful mind it’s a lot. To keep them straight, I use a simple nomenclature for my snippet abbreviations.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/textexpander-snippet-nomenclature/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/TextExpander-Snippet-Nomenclature.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/15/"><h3>15: Messed Up Mornings</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 9, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/early-riser">early-riser</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/kids">kids</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>The way people structure their morning routine can easily dictate your motivation for the day. But what happens when you can’t control the circumstances around your morning? What about kids?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/15/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Messed-Up-Mornings.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/keeping-up-with-ideas/"><h3>Keeping Up with Ideas</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 7, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/creativity">creativity</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/ideas">ideas</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Ideas are sometimes hard to come up with. But what happens when you have so many that you get lost? You have all these ideas begging you for attention and it becomes unclear which ones you should take on and which ones you should let go.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/keeping-up-with-ideas/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Keeping-Up-with-Ideas.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/generating-creative-energy/"><h3>Generating Creative Energy</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 4, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/creativity">creativity</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/energy">energy</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I had never thought of myself as a creative person until recently. Math and science have always been my strengths, so the arty side never took center stage.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/generating-creative-energy/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Generating-Creative-Energy.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/14/"><h3>14: How Much is Down Time Worth?</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 2, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/time">time</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/tracking">tracking</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’m starting to track my time. I’ve struggled with this in the past, but now I want to tie it to dollars. I want to know where my time is best spent.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/14/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/How-Much-is-Down-Time-Worth.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/13/"><h3>13: Wandering Brain</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 18, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/ideas">ideas</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I have more ideas than I can keep track of. And this is the whole of my creative process from idea development to storage.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/13/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Wandering-Brain.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/breaking-the-cycle/"><h3>Breaking the Cycle</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 13, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/addiction">addiction</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It’s time for a confession: I’m addicted to my phone. I want to check Twitter every five minutes and find myself refreshing Feedly every ten. And I hate it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/breaking-the-cycle/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Breaking-the-Cycle.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/reviews-and-scripting-learn-omnifocus-webinar/"><h3>Reviews and Scripting - Learn OmniFocus Webinar</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 11, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/webinar">webinar</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>A great asset behind OmniFocus is the community of people willing to share and ask questions; and one place to enjoy the resources this community creates is at <a href="http://learnomnifocus.com/?ref=11">Learn OmniFocus</a>.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/reviews-and-scripting-learn-omnifocus-webinar/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Reviews-and-Scripting-Learn-OmniFocus-Webinar.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/12/"><h3>12: The Higher Horizons</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 10, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/horizons">horizons</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>A quick overview of how I see the higher Horizons of GTD and why they are important. Also, I talk about why I think our babysitter is awesome.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/12/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/The-Higher-Horizons.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/take-a-break/"><h3>Take a Break</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 6, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/books">books</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/energy">energy</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Numerous times I’ve said that being able to put off work is an important step of being productive. And when you have a big push, it’s even more important to stop.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/take-a-break/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Take-a-break.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/working-with-omnifocus/"><h3>Working with OmniFocus</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 4, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/books">books</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>In the two days before this book launched I checked off 387 tasks in OmniFocus. And there’s no other tool I’d rather do it with.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/working-with-omnifocus/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/base/WorkingWithOmniFocus-Small.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/favorite-workflows/"><h3>Favorite Workflows</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 30, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/setups">setups</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/workflow">workflow</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve received a number of requests for more detail around my use of <a href="https://workflow.is/">Workflow</a> (<a href="https://geo.itunes.apple.com/us/app/workflow-powerful-automation/id915249334?mt=8&amp;at=1l3vnyQ">iTunes</a>). I’ve said that it saves time, but here are some details.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/favorite-workflows/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Favorite-Workflows.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/11/"><h3>11: Using Evernote for GTD</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 27, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/evernote">evernote</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Before I got into OmniFocus, I used Evernote for GTD. I had a few different structures, but I think I ended with a simple setup that worked well for me before I outgrew it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/11/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Using-Evernote-for-GTD.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/stop-being-productive/"><h3>Stop Being Productive</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 23, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/productivity">productivity</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>There are a lot of productivity bloggers and podcasters out there. And we’re all looking for ways to get better, faster, and create higher quality products. That’s pretty obvious when you read our articles.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/stop-being-productive/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Stop-Being-Productive.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/10/"><h3>10: Why I Don't Use Ads</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 20, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/ads">ads</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve avoided ads in my creative work from the beginning. But there’s a lot of pressure to use them as a way to make an income. In this episode, I explain why I don’t plan to change.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/10/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Why-I-Dont-Use-Ads.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/from-wordpress-google-to-jekyll-piwik/"><h3>From WordPress and Google to Jekyll and Piwik</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 16, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/jekyll">jekyll</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/piwik">piwik</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/development">development</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>This website has run on WordPress and Google Analytics from day one and they’ve both treated me pretty well. But I’ve started to see a need for more flexibility in the site, so it’s time for a big change.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/from-wordpress-google-to-jekyll-piwik/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/From-Wordpress-Google-to-Jekyll-Piwik.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/9/"><h3>9: Really? Journaling?</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 13, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/journaling">journaling</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I can’t believe I’ve started journaling every day. I’ve always equated journaling with writing in a diary, which is not for me. But the effects of not journaling caught me off-guard.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/9/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Really-Journaling.png?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-drafts/"><h3>Using Drafts</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 10, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/drafts">drafts</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/setups">setups</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p><a href="https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/id905337691?mt=8&amp;ign-mpt=uo%3D4">Drafts</a> is one of those apps that I cannot go without. The funny thing is that my tech-resistant wife is now dependent on it as well. And you can be sure that I am pretty excited about <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/5/">her use of it</a>.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-drafts/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Using-Drafts.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/8/"><h3>8: Waiting to Upgrade</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 6, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apple">apple</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hardware">hardware</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve started waiting to upgrade operating systems and hardware when new releases are available. My impulse is to upgrade immediately, but I’ve put it off for a variety of reasons.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/8/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Waiting-to-Upgrade.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/how-i-started-with-technology/"><h3>How I Started with Technology</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 2, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/development">development</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When I was 16 I bought my own Compaq laptop. Remember those? I had been using the family computer quite a bit, but this was my own computer. That was the beginning of my journey with technology.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/how-i-started-with-technology/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/How-I-Started-with-Technology.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/7/"><h3>7: Learning a Computer Language</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 29, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/development">development</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/research">research</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>People are sometimes scared to get into coding because they think it’s complicated to learn. It’s not complicated, so don’t be one of those people. In this episode I talk about how I got into development (with no schooling) and how I pick up new languages.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/7/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Learning-a-Computer-Language.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/sharing-a-computer/"><h3>Sharing a Computer</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 25, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hardware">hardware</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When I switched to the MacBook Pro, I also switched from using two computers to one. I know, I know, I was spoiled. But it made my life a lot easier and helped me accomplish a lot more.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/sharing-a-computer/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Sharing-a-Computer.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/6/"><h3>6: Collecting and Storing Research</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 22, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/evernote">evernote</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/research">research</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When you have a new project that you’re doing research on, you need a great way to grab and store that research. Referencing it later can be invaluable and save you the trouble of doing that same research multiple times.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/6/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Collecting-and-Storing-Research.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/scheduled-reviews-in-omnifocus/"><h3>Scheduled Reviews in OmniFocus</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 18, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/reviews">reviews</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Every Friday morning I do my <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/getting-things-done-reflect/">Weekly Review</a>. I do my Monthly Review on the first of the month and my Annual Review on the first of the year. How do I get OmniFocus to play nicely with this?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/scheduled-reviews-in-omnifocus/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Scheduled-Reviews-in-OmniFocus.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/5/"><h3>5: Developing a Task Management System</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 15, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/task management">task management</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>If you’ve made the decision to get into task management, congratulations! But you need to be intentional with getting started. Here’s a look at how I helped my wife put together her pen and paper system the first time.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/5/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Developing-a-Task-Management-System.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/writing-with-github/"><h3>Writing with GitHub</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 11, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/github">github</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/setups">setups</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/writing">writing</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve written about my use of <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/my-writing-setup/">Sublime Text for writing</a>, but I didn’t share how I manage the edits from my editor.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/writing-with-github/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Writing-with-GitHub.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/4/"><h3>4: Creating the First Checklist</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 8, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/checklists">checklists</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Creating a checklist for the first time isn’t always easy. And I did it wrong when I created the initial list for this podcast. I did figure out a better way, though.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/4/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Creating-the-First-Checklist.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/omnifocus-auto-parser/"><h3>OmniFocus Auto-Parser</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 4, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I love it when my systems do things automatically. In this case, I can capture an idea for a someday/maybe list and it ends up in the right place in OmniFocus.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/omnifocus-auto-parser/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/OmniFocus-Auto-Parser.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/3/"><h3>3: Keeping Up with Pain Pills</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 1, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Ugh. Dealing with water coming into the family room. And of course, I hurt myself and had to have surgery. And surgery leads to pain pills.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/3/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Keeping-Up-with-Pain-Pills.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/2/"><h3>2: The Dunbar Exception</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 31, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/communication">communication</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>In today’s world it’s easy to connect with more than 150 people. This is how keep up with 300+.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/2/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/The-Dunbar-Exception.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/1/"><h3>1: New Job New Contexts</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 30, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/contexts">contexts</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>If you go through a job change, you’ll need to change your GTD contexts. I walk you through my recent job transition and what I did to determine my new contexts.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/1/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/New-Job-New-Contexts.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/workflow-to-share-articles-with-twitter-handle/"><h3>Workflow to Share Articles with Twitter Handle</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 28, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/workflow">workflow</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I like to share articles on <a href="https://twitter.com/joebuhlig">Twitter</a>. And I want to make sure I give the author credit in the tweet. But it’s not always easy to find their Twitter handle.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/workflow-to-share-articles-with-twitter-handle/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Workflow-to-Share-Articles-with-Twitter-Handle.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/how-i-use-the-m-o-u-s-9/"><h3>How I Use the M.O.U.S. 9</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 21, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hardware">hardware</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I pulled my computer mouse out of my bag and the first thing he said was, “What on earth is that thing?” It was yet another confirmation that I’m strange.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/how-i-use-the-m-o-u-s-9/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/How-I-Use-the-M.O.U.S.-9.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/first-apps-on-a-new-mac/"><h3>First Apps on a New Mac</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 14, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apple">apple</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/textexpander">textexpander</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Last week, I mentioned I had purchased a new MacBook Pro. Instead of the migration process, I set it up as a new machine. That means I had to decide which apps needed to be installed first. Simple, right? Well, not so much.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/first-apps-on-a-new-mac/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/First-Apps-on-a-New-Mac.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/macbook-pro-vs-macbook-air/"><h3>MacBook Pro vs. MacBook Air</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 7, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apple">apple</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hardware">hardware</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve recently undergone a work transition that led me to purchasing a new MacBook Pro. My traveling work machine was a MacBook Air and I’ve found a few differences in the two that make me wish I’d done this earlier.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/macbook-pro-vs-macbook-air/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Macbook-Pro-Vs-MacBook-Air.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/why-i-use-omnifocus/"><h3>Why I Use OmniFocus</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 31, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Task managers. There are so many options available and it’s painful making a decision, especially when it takes real dollars to get into them.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/why-i-use-omnifocus/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Why-I-use-OmniFocus.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/my-mobile-office/"><h3>My Mobile Office</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 24, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/checklists">checklists</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hardware">hardware</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>As a homeworker, traveling has to be simple. If I need to connect with coworkers in person, I’m either on an airplane or in a rental car. In an effort to make it easy on myself, I have a backpack that serves as a mobile office.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/my-mobile-office/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/My-Mobile-Office.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/an-alternative-to-annual-goals/"><h3>An Alternative to Annual Goals</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 17, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/goals">goals</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve been struggling with goal-setting lately, enough that I <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/from-goals-to-guides/">abandoned my annual goals altogether</a>. But I’ve found that I want something to help guide the systems that I’m putting in place.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/an-alternative-to-annual-goals/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/An-Alternative-to-Annual-Goals.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/routine-vs-ritual/"><h3>Routine vs. Ritual</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 10, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/rituals">rituals</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/routines">routines</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>A while back I read <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/power-full-engagement-book-review/">The Power of Full Engagement</a>. The premise of the book is energy management and what you do each day to gain or use energy.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/routine-vs-ritual/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Routine-vs-Ritual.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-thebrain/"><h3>Using TheBrain</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 3, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/thebrain">thebrain</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Memory is a limited resource. And we usually ask it to do too much - from what task to work on to our kid’s birth date to a new business strategy.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-thebrain/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Using-TheBrain.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/different-uses-for-evernote/"><h3>Different Uses for Evernote</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 26, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/evernote">evernote</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>At 13,000 notes, I like to think I’m a big user of Evernote. From meeting notes and travel receipts to manuals and quotes, I keep a lot in Evernote.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/different-uses-for-evernote/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Different-Uses-for-Evernote.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/my-writing-setup/"><h3>My Writing Setup</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 19, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/setups">setups</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/writing">writing</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It’s been a little over a year since I started blogging and I’ve had a number of folks ask me what tools I use to write my articles. This is an outline of my process from idea to publish.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/my-writing-setup/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/My-Writing-Setup.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/from-goals-to-guides/"><h3>From Goals to Guides</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 12, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/goals">goals</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Remember the goal setting push at the beginning of the year? I’ve done it professionally and personally every year for four years and it <em>can</em> be motivating.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/from-goals-to-guides/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/From-Goals-to-Guides.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/my-omnifocus-home-screen/"><h3>My OmniFocus Home Screen</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 5, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/app">app</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>With one of the recent releases of <a href="https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/omnifocus-2/id904071710?mt=8">OmniFocus for iOS</a>, we were given the ability to rearrange perspectives on the OmniFocus home screen. Of course, I geeked out on this and created a custom view. Here’s what it looks like.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/my-omnifocus-home-screen/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/My-OmniFocus-Home-Screen.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/a-chaotic-week-with-gtd/"><h3>A Chaotic Week with GTD</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 29, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When I was getting started with GTD (Getting Things Done), I wondered what a week looked like for someone who used it. I never found anything along those lines and I recently had a week where I flexed it pretty hard. So I decided to give you a snapshot into my crazy week and see my GTD system in action.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/a-chaotic-week-with-gtd/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/A-chaotic-week-with-GTD.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/lost-in-transition/"><h3>Lost in Transition</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 22, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/time">time</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I read a lot of articles about time management and how to “reclaim an hour a day!” Most of those seem unrealistic. But in an attempt to find more time I discovered a single area that needed a lot of improvement.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/lost-in-transition/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Lost-in-Transition.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/working-the-focus-muscle/"><h3>Working the Focus Muscle</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 15, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/focus">focus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>When I started writing for this blog, it was easy. It was new and shiny and I wanted to sit down in the mornings and write for it. Eleven months into it, it’s harder.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/working-the-focus-muscle/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Working-the-Focus-Muscle.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/why-i-changed-my-newsletter-sign-up-process/"><h3>Why I Changed My Newsletter Sign-up Process</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 8, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/design">design</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/newsletter">newsletter</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>If you’ve been to this site in the past, you probably saw the email sign-up form slide up in the bottom right-hand corner. If you’ve been here on a mobile device, you saw the sign-up bar across the bottom. They’re both gone.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/why-i-changed-my-newsletter-sign-up-process/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Why-I-changed-my-newsletter-sign-up-process.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-omnifocus-for-somedaymaybe-lists/"><h3>Using Omnifocus for Someday/Maybe Lists</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">May 1, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>For a long time, I kept my active Next Actions in Omnifocus and my potential (someday/maybe) actions in Evernote. It worked, but it felt a bit cluttered so I moved it all into Omnifocus.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-omnifocus-for-somedaymaybe-lists/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Using-Omnifocus-for-Someday-Maybe-Lists.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/my-evening-routine/"><h3>My Evening Routine</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 24, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/routines">routines</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Much like a <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/my-morning-routine/">morning routine</a>, we all have an evening routine. Oftentimes, this means setting out clothes for tomorrow or getting the kids to bed. I do those as well, but I’ve also found satisfaction in reflecting on the day to put it into perspective.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/my-evening-routine/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/My-Evening-Routine.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/my-morning-routine/"><h3>My Morning Routine</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 17, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/early riser">early riser</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/routines">routines</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Everyone has a morning routine of some kind - even if it’s just “get up before the kids.” But I think it should be intentional and you can find yours by experimenting and learning what others do.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/my-morning-routine/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/My-Morning-Routine.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/gtd-contexts-proactive-vs-reactive/"><h3>GTD Contexts: Proactive vs. Reactive</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 10, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/contexts">contexts</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’ve always struggled with the contexts portion of GTD. I’ve tried tools, locations, energy levels, times of the day, mindsets, and on and on.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/gtd-contexts-proactive-vs-reactive/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/GTD-Contexts-Proactive-vs-Reactive.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/omnifocus-hotspot/"><h3>OmniFocus Hotspot</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Apr 3, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/files">files</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>In our digital age, we tend to receive a large number of files via email. And we need to review these files or make changes to them. As an <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/omnifocus-setup-workflow/">Omnifocus user</a>, that means I need to create tasks out of these files.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/omnifocus-hotspot/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Omnifocus-Hotspot.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/dont-ignore-push-notifications/"><h3>Don’t Ignore Push Notifications</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 27, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/notifications">notifications</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I was enjoying one of our first daddy-daughter dates. Of course, it was at a coffee shop. It was great! I drank my coffee and Cutie watched the constant movement of people between bites of her cookie.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/dont-ignore-push-notifications/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Don't-Ignore-Push-Notifications.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/siri-to-omnifocus/"><h3>Siri to Omnifocus</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 20, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/capture">capture</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/siri">siri</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I don’t have a daily commute but I still find myself in the car having ideas from time to time. I don’t want to lose those ideas, but I shouldn’t be typing into my phone or writing things while I’m driving.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/siri-to-omnifocus/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Siri-to-Omnifocus.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/the-internet-separation-layer/"><h3>The Internet Separation Layer</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 13, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/communication">communication</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>We do it almost every day. We communicate with another person using a screen of some kind - social media, texts, emails, instant messages.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/the-internet-separation-layer/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/The-Internet-Separation-Layer.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/saving-full-articles-in-evernote-from-rss/"><h3>Saving Full Articles in Evernote from RSS</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Mar 6, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/evernote">evernote</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/rss">rss</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>There is no shortage of articles on the web. Reading (or at least skimming) hundreds of articles can be done easily in less than an hour. But have you ever tried keeping a record of all those articles?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/saving-full-articles-in-evernote-from-rss/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Saving-Full-Articles-in-Evernote-from-RSS.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/sloppy-productivity/"><h3>Sloppy Productivity</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 27, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/productivity">productivity</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>If you’ve read one article on this blog, you’ll know that I’m a productivity nut. But there’s a side to productivity that I haven’t seen mentioned very often - <em>life</em>.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/sloppy-productivity/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Sloppy-Productivity.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/recurring-checklists-in-evernote/"><h3>Recurring Checklists in Evernote</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 20, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/checklists">checklists</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/evernote">evernote</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>One of the first notes many Evernote users create is a checklist of some kind. It could be a grocery list, a to-do list for the day, or a morning routine.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/recurring-checklists-in-evernote/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Recurring-Checklists-in-Evernote.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/instant-gratification-vs-instant-perspective/"><h3>Instant Gratification vs. Instant Perspective</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 13, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gratification">gratification</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/perspective">perspective</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I finished (second) breakfast and sat down at my computer to pull together analytics on one of my company’s websites. At that moment, a coworker texted me a question. I don’t remember what the question was about, but I do remember that it was almost an hour before I managed to get back to work.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/instant-gratification-vs-instant-perspective/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Instant-Gratification-vs-Instant-Perspective.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/every-body-saying-book-review/"><h3>What Every BODY Is Saying [Book Review]</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Feb 6, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/books">books</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Have you ever had a <em>feeling</em> that someone is uncomfortable in a conversation? Were you able to point out the nonverbal cues that gave you that feeling?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/every-body-saying-book-review/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/What-Every-BODY-is-Saying-Book-Review.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/evernote-setup-workflow/"><h3>My Evernote Setup and Workflow</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 23, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/evernote">evernote</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/setups">setups</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Evernote is a handy tool with a <em>lot</em> of ways to use it – so many that it gets really hard to figure out how to set it up.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/evernote-setup-workflow/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/My-Evernote-Setup-and-Workflow.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/danger-infinity-apps/"><h3>The Danger of Infinity Apps</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 16, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>An <em>infinity</em> app is one with a never-ending stream of some kind. It’s an app that always has new updates for you to consume.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/danger-infinity-apps/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/The-Danger-of-Infinity-Apps.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/keeping-goals/"><h3>Keeping Up With Your Goals</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jan 2, 2015</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/evernote">evernote</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/goals">goals</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It’s resolution time! Or not. There are a plethora of articles telling you to set goals as opposed to resolutions. The term doesn’t really matter. They’ll fail without a plan behind them.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/keeping-goals/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Keeping-Up-with-Your-Goals.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/inbox/"><h3>What is an Inbox?</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 26, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/inbox">inbox</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>An inbox can be your mailbox, your email inbox, and even a physical tray. But those aren’t the only places that stuff lands.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/inbox/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/What-is-an-Inbox.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/making-time-contexts/"><h3>Making Time for Contexts</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 19, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/contexts">contexts</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>The difficult part of <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/getting-things-done-introduction/">Getting Things Done</a> (GTD) for me is contexts. What lists should I be using when I’m completing tasks?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/making-time-contexts/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Making-Time-for-Contexts.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/productivity-vs-presence/"><h3>Productivity vs. Presence</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 12, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/presence">presence</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/productivity">productivity</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>We are taught to accomplish tasks. In school and work, grades and reviews measure our ability to accurately complete an assignment.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/productivity-vs-presence/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Productivity-vs-Presence.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/getting-things-done-day-life/"><h3>Getting Things Done: A Day in the Life</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Dec 5, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>There are a lot of articles about setting up GTD. But I don’t see many that show what a typical day looks like when you adopt the framework.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/getting-things-done-day-life/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/GTD-A-Day-in-the-Life.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>
