<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/getting-things-done-engage/"><h3>Getting Things Done: Engage</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 28, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/engage">engage</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Deciding what to work on can be simple – it doesn’t have to be stressful. GTD can help you make the decision quickly and easily.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/getting-things-done-engage/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/GTD-Engage.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/getting-things-done-reflect/"><h3>Getting Things Done: Reflect</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 21, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/reviews">reviews</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>The Weekly Review is the most important part of the GTD process. Without it, you’ll have loose ends and you’ll no longer trust your system.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/getting-things-done-reflect/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/GTD-Reflect.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/getting-things-done-organize/"><h3>Getting Things Done: Organize</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 14, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/organize">organize</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Organize. The favorite step of most GTDers. This is where you set up tools for tracking each bucket from the <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/getting-things-done-clarify/">Clarify step</a>.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/getting-things-done-organize/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/GTD-Organize.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/getting-things-done-clarify/"><h3>Getting Things Done: Clarify</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Nov 7, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/clarify">clarify</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/contexts">contexts</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>A lot of people write things down but fail to do anything with it afterwards. It just dies on the paper. Why write it down if you’ll never look at it again?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/getting-things-done-clarify/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/GTD-Clarify.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/getting-things-done-capture/"><h3>Getting Things Done: Capture</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 31, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/capture">capture</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/inbox">inbox</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p><em>Capture</em> is the process of collecting ideas and actions. You’re accumulating task items, reference material, or even trash and putting them in an inbox of some kind.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/getting-things-done-capture/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/GTD-Capture.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/getting-things-done-introduction/"><h3>Getting Things Done: Introduction</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 24, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Why do we think we can manage our lives with only our memory? It’s certainly flawed. It doesn’t even remind us of what we need when we need it. It waits until we’re in bed and can’t do anything about it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/getting-things-done-introduction/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/GTD-Introduction.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/why-getting-up-early/"><h3>The “Why” of Getting Up Early</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 17, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/early riser">early riser</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>It’s 4:55 am. I roll over to check the clock and realize I’m awake before my alarm goes off. That’s always a good feeling. But why am I awake at this time of day?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/why-getting-up-early/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/The-Why-of-Getting-Up-Early.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/seasons-tasks/"><h3>Seasons of Tasks</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 10, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/seasons">seasons</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>The mornings are getting colder and the animals are preparing for winter. Another weather change is coming. And it’s a great reminder that we, too, should be preparing for the next season.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/seasons-tasks/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Seasons-of-Tasks.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/power-full-engagement-book-review/"><h3>The Power of Full Engagement [Book Review]</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Oct 3, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/books">books</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/energy">energy</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>There’s a lot of advice on the web about managing your time. Everyone seems to have the golden ticket that will pull time out of thin air. But what if time isn’t the key to being fully engaged?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/power-full-engagement-book-review/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/The-Power-of-Full-Engagement-Book-Review.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/creating-personal-project-codes/"><h3>Creating Personal Project Codes</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 26, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/projects">projects</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Last week I wrote about <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/managing-project-information/">managing information for projects</a>. In that post I revealed the project codes I use, and now we’re going to talk about how to create them.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/creating-personal-project-codes/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Creating-Personal-Project-Codes.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/managing-project-information/"><h3>Managing Project Information</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 19, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/projects">projects</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Using David Allen’s definition, a project is anything that requires more than one action to complete. This can range from building a new web application to replacing the refrigerator filter.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/managing-project-information/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Managing-Project-Information.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/pros-cons-apple-watch/"><h3>Pros and Cons of Apple Watch</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 12, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apple">apple</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/watch">watch</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Last Tuesday, Apple unveiled their new Smart Watch— the <a href="http://www.apple.com/watch/">Apple Watch</a>. It came with a lot of fanfare and definitely looks compelling. But is it really going to be worth it?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/pros-cons-apple-watch/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Pros-and-Cons-of-Apple-Watch.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/file-naming-disorganization/"><h3>File Naming and (Dis)Organization</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Sep 5, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/files">files</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Naming and organizing files is extremely important. In today’s world, we can keep track of thousands of files. And with versioning getting to be a big deal, we have to have a way to keep track of it all.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/file-naming-disorganization/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/File-Naming-and-(Dis)Organization.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/simple-trick-naming-tags/"><h3>A Simple Trick for Naming Tags</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 29, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/evernote">evernote</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/tags">tags</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>The search capabilities of many tools today is impressive. We can search titles, notes, filenames, and even the contents of a file. But if you’re searching for a tag, it can give you a lot more than you expected.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/simple-trick-naming-tags/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/A-simple-trick-for-naming-tags.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/developing-personal-communication-cycle/"><h3>Developing a Personal Communication Cycle</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 22, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/communication">communication</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Recently a coworker confronted me on something I struggle with. Communicating. I’m introverted and love to come up with ideas, but I’m terrible at deciding when to share those ideas.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/developing-personal-communication-cycle/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Developing-a-Personal-Communication-Cycle.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/aint-broke-dont-fix/"><h3>If It Ain’t Broke, Don’t Fix It. Why Not?</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 15, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/change">change</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p><em>We’ve always done it that way. But it works. Why change it? If it ain’t broke, don’t fix it.</em> When I hear these phrases I cringe. Yes, it works. Yes, it’s a smooth system. Yes, we’re familiar with it. <strong>But that doesn’t mean it shouldn’t change.</strong></p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/aint-broke-dont-fix/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/If-it-ain't-broke-don't-fix-it-why-not.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/choosing-3-important-tasks-day/"><h3>Choosing the 3 Most Important Tasks for the Day</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 8, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/time">time</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I’m terrible at estimating time. I always think that I can complete more than I truly can. I throw 8 things on a list for the day and go. I can complete them all… or not. If I’m honest with myself, I know that I can’t do it all.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/choosing-3-important-tasks-day/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Choosing-the-3-MIT-for-the-Day.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/getting-started-task-management/"><h3>Getting Started with Task Management</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Aug 1, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/task management">task management</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I started keeping lists a few years ago. I had a lot going on and forgetting things was becoming normal. I needed a way to manage tasks since my brain was terrible at it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/getting-started-task-management/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Getting-Started-with-Task-Management.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/gaining-perspective-daily-review/"><h3>Gaining Perspective with a Daily Review</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 25, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/perspective">perspective</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/reviews">reviews</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>How many times have you closed up shop for the day and wondered what happened? Ever get up in the morning and ask yourself what you should do today?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/gaining-perspective-daily-review/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Gaining-Perspective-with-a-Daily-Review.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/adding-contacts-business-cards-evernote/"><h3>Adding Contacts from Business Cards with Evernote</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 18, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/evernote">evernote</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I had just introduced myself to the executive leading the meeting. He handed me his business card and I quickly snapped a picture of it with my phone. A few seconds later his phone dinged. He glanced at his phone, then looked at me in shock.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/adding-contacts-business-cards-evernote/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Adding-Contacts-from-Business-Cards-with-Evernote.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/using-text-expander/"><h3>Using a Text Expander</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 11, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/textexpander">textexpander</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Do you ever find yourself typing the same thing over and over again? Stuff like an email address, the date, a URL, or even a template of some kind? If so, a text expansion app might be just what you need.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/using-text-expander/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Using-a-Text-Expander.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/omnifocus-setup-workflow/"><h3>My Omnifocus Setup and Workflow</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jul 4, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/apps">apps</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/gtd">gtd</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/omnifocus">omnifocus</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/setups">setups</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p><a href="https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/omnifocus-2/id867299399?mt=12&amp;uo=4&amp;at=1l3vnyQ">OmniFocus</a> is a powerful tool designed to follow David Allen’s <a href="http://gettingthingsdone.com/">Getting Things Done</a>. I go into the <a href="http://joebuhlig.com/getting-things-done-introduction/">details of GTD here</a> but the simple version is that it’s a method of getting things out of your mind and into a trusted organizational system. The main purpose is to free up your mind to have ideas, not hold them.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/omnifocus-setup-workflow/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/My-Omnifocus-Setup-and-Workflow.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/what-is-an-hpda-and-how-do-i-use-it/"><h3>What Is An hPDA and How Do I Use It?</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 27, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hpda">hpda</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/capture">capture</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Ideas and reminders come to us when we’re not ready for them or when we can’t do anything about them. We remember to clean out the gutters when it’s raining. An idea for a new website comes to us when we’re eating dinner. What do you do with those?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/what-is-an-hpda-and-how-do-i-use-it/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/What-is-an-hPDA.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/leaving-phone/"><h3>Leaving Your Phone</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 20, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>Have you ever intentionally left your phone in the car while on a date? Was it freeing or did it feel like prison? Have you ever, like me, found yourself on Twitter while at the dinner table? Was that any different?</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/leaving-phone/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Leaving-Your-Phone.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/escaping-corporate-email-habit/"><h3>Escaping the Corporate Email Habit</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 10, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/email">email</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/communication">communication</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I used to pride myself in having one of the fastest email replies in the office. If you sent me an email, I was back to you in less than 10 minutes. Sometimes 5.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/escaping-corporate-email-habit/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Escaping-the-Corporate-Email-Habit.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/desktop-tower-move/"><h3>Desktop Tower Move</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 9, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/hardware">hardware</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>I didn’t want to write this post. I don’t want you to read it. My wife wanted me to write it. I hesitated. Writing it forces me to admit that I’m picky and maybe neurotic. So it’s probably a good thing that I did write it.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/desktop-tower-move/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Desktop-Tower-Move.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>

<div class="feed-item"><div class="feed-content-wrapper"><div class="feed-content"><div class="feed-title"><a href="/put-distractions-place/"><h3>Put Distractions in Their Place</h3></a></div><div class="feed-meta-mobile"><div class="meta-item">Jun 8, 2014</div><div class="meta-item">Joe Buhlig</div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/distractions">distractions</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div><div class="meta-item"><a class="meta-tag" href="/tag/life">life</a><div class="meta-tag-arrow"></div></div></div><div class="feed-excerpt"><p>We have everything at our fingertips. We can look something up instantly and connect with almost anyone at any time.</p></div></div></div><div class="feed-pic"><a href="/put-distractions-place/"><img class="hidden" src=data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhAQABAAAAACH5BAEKAAEALAAAAAABAAEAAAICTAEAOw== data-src="/assets/posts/Put-Distractions-In-Their-Place.jpg?v=15" /></a></div></div>
